content:
Dear all,

I am browsing through the mathlib docs, and have figured some things out but still have questions.

  1. What do the colors on the left side of each item designate? Is there a color coding available as a reference? I presume it is something about missing or unsafe implementations etc. More specifically?

  2. What is the difference between equations and the source link?

  3. In some situations, there are identical names in different namespaces, like Init.Data and Lean.Data. What is the relationship between those names?

More generally I have tons of questions that would be better suited for a dedicated Q&A site rather than a chat; this could aggregate many beginner questions and alleviate this forum for answering the same things over and over again. Is there such a place (perhaps on Stack Exchange)?

Thank you all!
Note that https://proofassistants.stackexchange.com/ does exist, though I think your questions are probably better addressed here
1. There's no key to speak of, but generally the colors just correspond to the first word of the declaration (def/theorem/structure/etc)

1. One summarizes the definition, one actually takes you to the exact source code that defines it (which includes comments). The equation is the _generated_ output; some definitions may have no source at all, while others might use tactics to generate their equations.
Oh, so the colors have nothing to do with the implementation status of each item. OK!
Ioannis Konstantoulas has marked this topic as resolved.
If it's in the docs in the first place, then it's almost guaranteed to be implemented!
Reading safety, docs#Quot.unquot is an example of how something unsafe is rendered (i.e., nothing special besides the unsafe keyword)
